titleStmt.title: Arabidopsis Synaptotagmin 2 Participates in Pollen Germination and Tube Growth and Is Delivered to Plasma Membrane via Conventional Secretion

analytic.title: Arabidopsis Synaptotagmin 2 Participates in Pollen Germination and Tube Growth and Is Delivered to Plasma Membrane via Conventional Secretion

biblStruct.note: Received: February 13, 2015 Revised: August 18, 2015 Accepted: September 5, 2015

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Arabidopsis synaptotagmin 2 (SYT2) has been reported to participate in an unconventional secretory pathway in somatic cells. Our results showed that SYT2 was expressed mainly in the pollen of Arabidopsis thaliana. The pollen of syt2 T-DNA and RNA interference mutant lines exhibited reduced total germination and impeded pollen tube growth. Analysis of the expression of SYT2-GFP fusion protein in the pollen tube indicates that SYT2 was localized to distinct, patchy compartments but could co-localize with the Golgi markers, BODIPY TR C5 ceramide and GmMan1-mCherry. However, SYT2-DsRed-E5 was localized to the plasma membrane in Arabidopsis suspension cells, in addition to the Golgi apparatus. The localization of SYT2 at the plasma membrane was further supported by immunofluorescence staining in pollen tubes. Moreover, brefeldin A treatment inhibited the transport of SYT2 to the plasma membrane and caused SYT2 to aggregate and form enlarged compartments. Truncation of the SYT2-C2AB domains also resulted in retention of SYT2 in the Golgi apparatus. An in vitro phospholipid-binding assay showed that SYT2-C2AB domains bind to the phospholipid membrane in a calcium-dependent manner. Take together, our results indicated that SYT2 was required for pollen germination and pollen tube growth, and was involved in conventional exocytosis.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Pollen tubes exhibit very rapid polar tip growth in which cell expansion occurs only at the extreme apex of the cell. During tip growth, the tips of the pollen tubes undergo very active exocytosis to deliver new components to the plasma membrane and the cell walls, as well as to secrete proteins via the Golgi apparatus-derived secretory vesicles (Camacho and Malhó , 2003;Szumlanski and Nielsen, 2009;Chae and Lord, 2011;Onelli and Moscatelli, 2013). It was found that the tip-focused Ca 2+ gradient is essential for pollen tube growth and promotes the transport, priming, and fusion of the secretory vesicles to the plasma membrane (Coelho and Malhó , 2006;Ge et al., 2007;Chen et al., 2015). Synaptotagmins (Syt) constitute a family of membranetrafficking proteins that regulate exo/endocytosis via membrane fusion in animal cells (Jahn et al., 2003;Craxton, 2004) and act as calcium sensors (Chapman, 2002;Tucker and Chapman, 2002). Syt1 is a synaptic-vesicle-localized protein that facilitates SNARE-catalyzed membrane fusion in exocytosis after sensing Ca 2+ influx (Tucker et al., 2004;Apodaca, 2006;Martens et al., 2007). Syt2 plays an additional and non-redundant role in controlling synaptic transmission in Ca 2+ -triggered neurotransmitter release, which is similar to the role of Syt1 (Pang et al., 2006;Leitzell, 2007). Syt7 has been proposed to regulate calcium-dependent membrane fusion of lysosomes in wound repair (Martinez et al., 2000;Caler et al., 2001;Reddy et al., 2001;Jaiswal et al., 2004). In addition, Syt7 has been reported to function as a Ca 2+ sensor in calcium-induced glucagon exocytosis (Gustavsson et al., 2009). Syt1, Syt2, and Syt9 are known as Ca 2+ sensors and modulate fast synchronous neurotransmitter release (Xu et al., 2007). Syt9 regulates Ca 2+ -dependent exocytosis in pancreatic islets and PC12 cells (Fukuda et al., 2002;Iezzi et al., 2004Iezzi et al., , 2005.

Seventeen isoforms of synaptotagmins have been reported in vertebrate animals (Bhalla et al., 2008). All synaptotagmins have a similar structure: an N-terminal transmembrane (TM) region, a linker of variable length, and two tandem C2 domains, C2A and C2B (Craxton, 2007). The C2 domains, first identified in the second conserved regulatory domain of the classical protein kinase C (Coussens et al., 1986;Cho and Stahelin, 2006), are independently folded protein modules that bind to Ca 2+ and phospholipids (Sutton et al., 1995;Fernandez et al., 2001). C2A and C2B domains of Syt1 are similar structures, consisting of compact b-sandwiches with eight b-strands connected by three flexible loops (Fernandez et al., 2001;Chapman, 2002). Five aspartic acid residues coordinating Ca 2+ in loop1 and loop3 of each C2 domain of Syt1 are conserved only in a subset of synaptotagmins (Chapman, 2002;Koh and Bellen, 2003).

The Arabidopsis genome includes five genes that encode synaptotagmin-like proteins (Craxton, 2004). SYT1 (also called SytA) helps maintain the integrity of the plasma membrane when the membrane is disrupted by freezing (Yamazaki et al., 2008) and osmotic stress (Schapire et al., 2008). Another study illustrated SYT1 regulation of endocytosis and mediation of the transport of virus movement proteins between cells (Lewis and Lazarowitz, 2010;Uchiyama et al., 2014). SYT1 accumulates at the haustorial membrane around the invading oomycete Phytophthora infestans in Nicotiana benthamiana host leaf cells (Lu et al., 2012;Bozkurt et al., 2014). Moreover, SYT1 also accumulates in a fraction of detergent-resistant plasma membrane microdomains after cold acclimation (Minami et al., 2009;Takahashi et al., 2013) and was detected as an interacting partner of the brassinosteroid receptor kinase BRI1 (Wang et al., 2013). A recent study also demonstrated that Arabidopsis SYT1 is a component of ER-PM contact sites, which maintain the mechanical stability of the cells (Perez Sancho et al., 2015). Surprisingly, synaptotagmin and the eyespot assembly proteins EYE3 and SOUL3 have recently been reported in the plastoglubuli proteome of halotolerant green algae Dunaliella (Davidi et al., 2015). Finally, synaptotagmin was involved in rhizobia-legume symbiosis in Medicago spp. (Rose et al., 2012) and in roots of Robinia pseudoacacia entering symbiosis with Mesorhizobium amorphae (Chen et al., 2013).

The 35S promoter-driven overexpression of SYT2 in Arabidopsis leaf and root cells showed SYT2 localization to the Golgi apparatus and involvement in the regulation of unconventional secretion of hygromycin B phosphotransferase (Zhang et al., 2011). However, the intrinsic physiological role of SYT2 in Arabidopsis has not been determined.

In this study, we have demonstrated that SYT2 is expressed mainly in pollen and localizes to the Golgi apparatus. SYT2 is delivered to the plasma membrane via brefeldin A (BFA)-sensitive secretory vesicles. The C2 domains of SYT2 play a crucial role in directing SYT2 to the plasma membrane. To our knowledge, SYT2 is the first Arabidopsis synaptotagmin demonstrated to participate in conventional secretion and play a role in pollen germination and pollen tube tip growth.

div.head: Arabidopsis SYT2 Is Expressed Mainly in Pollen Grains
div.p: To understand the physiological role of Arabidopsis SYT2, we analyzed SYT2 gene expression in various organs using a gene-specific RT-PCR and a promoter:GUS reporter system. The result of real-time PCR showed that SYT2 was expressed mainly in freshly harvested and non-hydrated pollen grains, whereas its expression was relatively very low in roots, stems, leaves, and siliques ( Figure 1A). The results of semiquantitative RT-PCR also indicated a high level of SYT2 transcript in the inflorescence and stamens (Supplemental Figure 1).

In a tissue-specific expression study of SYT2, a native SYT2 promoter was fused to a GUS reporter gene and introduced into wild-type Arabidopsis. Two independent lines of pSYT2:GUS transgenic Arabidopsis (made by two different laboratories) were selected for an intermediate level of gene expression from a transgenic population according to quantitative fluorometric and qualitative histochemical GUS analyses. The histochemical and fluorometric GUS assay showed that the highest GUS activity was in the inflorescence ( Figure 1B and Supplemental Figure 2A). Quantitative analysis of SYT2 promoter activity was conducted using one of the transgenic lines and showed that maximum activity was in flower buds, shortly before anthesis ( Figure 1C), and the strongest signal was in stamens and, to a lesser extent, pistils ( Figure 1D).
Detailed histochemical examination suggested that the GUS staining was limited to developing female gametophytes Molecular Plant --, 1-14, --2015 ª The Author 2015.

(unfertilized embryo sacs; Figure 1E) and developing male gametophytes (pollen grains; Figure 1F and Supplemental Figure 2B). The growing pollen tubes showed strong GUS staining under in vitro conditions ( Figure 1G). Since GUS staining was present both in ovules and pollen tubes, we performed reciprocal crossing of the pSYT2:GUS transgenic line with wild-type Arabidopsis to discriminate these two signals after pollination. No GUS staining was observed in the wildtype ovules after pollination with transgenic pollen grains; nevertheless, the staining of transgenic pollen tubes was evident in the pistils ( Figure 1H). These data suggested that SYT2 was also expressed in pollen tubes grown in vivo in pistils. On the other hand, after the pistils of transgenic plants were pollinated by pollen from wild-type plants, GUS staining of the fertilized and enlarged ovules became weaker and disappeared ( Figure 1I), while the unpollinated ovules remained small and strongly stained ( Figure 1J). These results suggested that SYT2 could play a role in the development of embryo sacs and pollen grains, as well as in the pollen germination and tip growth of pollen tubes.

div.head: SYT2 Mutants Show Decreased Total Pollen Germination Percentages and Pollen Tube Lengths Compared with Wild-Type Pollen Tubes
div.p: We obtained three Arabidopsis mutants, named syt2-1, syt2-2, and syt2-3, from the SALK collection (i.e., SALK_133731, SALK_016690, and SALK_072947) with T-DNA located in the second intron, the ninth exon, and another position of the ninth exon of At1G20800, respectively (Figure 2A). Mutant lines with different T-DNA insertion sites on the SYT2 locus were screened by genomic PCR with SYT2 and T-DNA borderspecific primers (Supplemental Table 1).

The genotyping results are shown in Figure 2B. The level of the SYT2 transcript in syt2-2 was very low and could not be Figure 1B). The fluorescence intensity of the stages was normalized to that of 1.5-mm-long flower buds. Error bars represent ±SEs of the mean (n = 10). . Ovules remained stainless after pollination (arrowheads). div.head: SYT2 in Pollen Tube Growth
div.p: Molecular Plant detected by RT-PCR. Syt2-1 and syt2-3 only showed a trace amount of SYT2 transcripts ( Figure 2C).

Arabidopsis RNAi lines were also generated to investigate the function of SYT2 (Supplemental Figure 3). One SYT2-RNAi line with reduced SYT2 (RNAi-#5) expression was identified by RT-PCR ( Figure 2C) and used for further investigation of phenotype.

Pollen germination percentages of the homozygous T-DNA insertion mutants (syt2-1, syt2-2, and syt2-3) and an RNAi line (RNAi-#5) were calculated and compared with the wild-type by in vitro means of germination assays. Results showed that the relative germination efficiency of pollen from T-DNA mutants ranged from 54.6% to 78.2% at 5 h after imbibition, and the relative germination efficiency of pollen from the RNAi-#5 line was 52.0% ( Figure 2D). We also calculated the germination percentages at 6.5 h after imbibition, and the data showed that both the SYT2 mutants and wild-type pollen grains already reached their maximal germination percentages after 5 h of imbibition (Supplemental Table 2). The final pollen germination percentages of SYT2 mutants were lower than that of wildtype. These results indicated that SYT2 contributed to pollen viability.

To determine whether mutation of the SYT2 gene affected pollen tube elongation, we measured the lengths of pollen tubes of wildtype and mutant lines germinated for 5 h on in vitro medium. Average lengths of the pollen tubes were 115 mm in the wild-type and from 77 to 100 mm in the mutants (Figure 2E). The homozygous syt2-1, syt2-2, syt2-3, and RNAi-#5 lines represented a 13.1%, 18.3%, 25.2%, and 32.2% reduction in the average length of pollen tubes, respectively. More than 66% of wild-type pollen tubes were longer than 95 mm and only 0.3% were shorter than 55 mm. The mutants had a markedly lower percentage of pollen tubes longer than 95 mm, compared with the wild-type. The proportions of pollen tubes <55 mm were considerably higher in the mutant lines, especially the RNAi mutant. We found 30.9% of RNAi-#5 pollen tubes to be <55 mm ( Figure 2E). We also measured the lengths of pollen tubes from 1 h to 3 h, and the results showed that the pollen of SYT2 mutants had already germinated and grown much the same length as that of wild-type at 1 h (Supplemental Figure 4). However, the growth rates of pollen tubes of SYT2 mutants were slower than that of wild-type after 1 h. In addition, the growth rates of pollen tubes of both wild-type and the mutant lines were very slow after 5 h of imbibition, but the growth rate of SYT2 mutant was still lower than that of wild-type (Supplemental Table 2). Thus, we showed that the shorter pollen tubes of SYT2 mutants were not due to delayed germination but retarded elongation.

These data demonstrated that the SYT2 gene also played a role in elongation of pollen tubes. Although the pollen tubes of SYT2 mutants were shorter than wild-type pollen tubes, the mutants exhibited pollen tubes long enough to accomplish fertilization, which may explain the lack of a marked difference in seed setting percentage between the mutants and wild-type plants. P1 (forward) and P2 (reverse) are primers for syt2-1 diagnostic PCR. P1 0 (forward) and P2 0 (reverse) are primers for diagnostic PCRs of syt2-2 and syt2-3. LBb1.3 is the primer specific to the T-DNA. RT Fw and RT Rev represent primers used for RT-PCR analysis. aa, amino acids. (B) PCR analysis of the three T-DNA insertion lines. (C) SYT2 expression analysis of three T-DNA insertion lines (syt2-1, syt2-2, syt2-3) and one RNAi mutant (RNAi-#5). To compare SYT2 with SYT1, SYT1 was used as a positive control. The Actin2 gene was used as an internal control. (D) Relative pollen germination efficiency of Col-0 and SYT2 mutants. The upper panel shows micrographs of pollen grains and pollen tubes of the wild-type (Col-WT) and syt2 mutant lines (syt2-1, syt2-2, syt2-3, and RNAi-#5). The percentage germination of pollen from wild-type plants is defined as 100%. The histogram shows the relative germination efficiency of the pollen grains (Student's t-test, *p < 0.05, **p < 0.001). Error bars represent ±SE (n R 70) from three independent experiments. (E) Pollen tube lengths and frequency distributions of different tube lengths. The upper histogram shows the pollen tube lengths of the wild-type and mutants. The pollen tube lengths of mutants were shorter than those of the wild-type (Mann-Whitney U test; **p < 0.001). The stacked bar chart below shows the statistical frequency distribution of pollen tubes lengths <55 mm, 55-95 mm, and >95 mm. Bar colors represent tube length: yellow, >95 mm; green, 55-95 mm; and blue, <55 mm. Error bars represent ±SE (n R 200) from three biological repeats.

div.head: SYT2-GFP is Localized Mainly to the Golgi Apparatus
div.p: To evaluate the subcellular localization of SYT2, two plant expression systems were used, including stable expression of SYT2-GFP driven by a pLAT52 promoter in transgenic Arabidopsis and transient expression of SYT2-GFP in tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum L.) pollen grains by microparticle bombardment with a pLAT52:SYT2-GFP construct. The results for both showed that the SYT2-GFP fusion protein was localized to distinct patches in the growing pollen tubes but rarely to the plasma membrane ( Figure 3, Supplemental Figure 5Aa and 5Ac). In stable transgenic pLAT52:SYT2-GFP Arabidopsis, the SYT2-GFP-containing compartments were co-localized with the Golgi dye BODIPY TR C5 ceramide (B-34400; Invitrogen) and the Golgi marker GmMan1-mCh, the cytoplasmic tail and transmembrane domain of GmMan1 fused with mCherry (Nelson et al., 2007), which was transiently expressed by particle bombardment but not the endocytic vesicle marker FM4-64 and the ER-Tracker Blue-White DPX ( Figure 3A). To further examine the subcellular localization of SYT2-GFP, we treated the pollen tubes with the secretion inhibitor BFA (35.6 mM) and the late endosomes/ autophagy inhibitor wortmannin (10 mM) for 30 min after 3 h of germination. The results showed that SYT2-GFP formed enlarged aggregates after BFA treatment and decorated around the FM4-64-stained BFA compartments featuring the Golgi localization of SYT2-GFP ( Figure 3B). Wortmannin slightly changed the morphology of SYT2-GFP vesicles in the pollen tubes, but SYT2-GFP was not accumulated into the wortmannin-induced multivesicular compartments indicating that SYT2-GFP was not localized to the trans-Golgi network and the prevacuoles ( Figure 3B).

As a control, the cytosolic GFP protein alone showed diffuse distribution in the cytoplasm and nucleus in tobacco pollen tubes (Supplemental Figure 5Ab). The results of transiently transforming pLAT52:SYT2-GFP and pLAT52:GFP into tobacco pollen showed results similar to those in Arabidopsis ( Figure 3C).

To confirm the subcellular localization of SYT2 in pollen tubes, we performed immunofluorescence labeling of SYT2 using a SYT2specific antibody. The results indicated that SYT2 was localized not only to the Golgi apparatus but also to the plasma membrane in pollen tubes (Supplemental Figure 6). However, since the SYT2-GFP fluorescence signal was very weak on the margin of transgenic pollen tubes, it was difficult to determine if SYT2 was located on the plasma membrane or the endocytosisderived vesicles in the pollen tubes.

div.head: SYT2 Is Transported from the Golgi Apparatus to the Plasma Membrane
div.p: To confirm that SYT2 was localized to the plasma membrane, we first examined the subcellular localization of SYT2 by expressing SYT2-GFP in Arabidopsis suspension cells and found that the SYT2-GFP signal had a patchy distribution around the (A) SYT2-GFP driven by the LAT52 promoter showed no co-localization either with endocytic vesicles labeled with 2 mM of FM4-64 (30 min) or with ER lumen labeled with 100 nM of ER-Tracker Blue-White DPX (20 min) but the co-localization with the Golgi apparatus labeled respectively with 5 mM of C5 ceramide (1 h) and the Golgi marker (GmMan1-mCh) in Arabidopsis thaliana L. pollen tubes. Bars represent 10 mm. (B) SYT2-GFP aggregated and surrounded the FM4-64-stained BFA bodies (arrowheads) after 35.6 mM of BFA treatment (30 min), but did not incorporate into the FM4-64-stained wortmannin-induced compartment (arrows) after 10 mM of wortmannin treatment (30 min) in Arabidopsis thaliana L. pollen tubes. Bars represent 10 mm. (C) SYT2-GFP showed no co-localization with FM4-64 (2 mM, 10 min)-stained endocytic vesicles, but overlapped with C5 ceramide (5 mM, 1 h)-stained Golgi apparatus in tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum L.) pollen tubes. Bars represent 5 mm. DIC, Differential Interference Contrast.

div.head: SYT2 in Pollen Tube Growth
div.p: Molecular Plant nucleus in suspension cells, whereas GFP alone showed diffuse localization in the cytosol and inside the nucleus (Supplemental Figure 5B). However, the SYT2-GFP signal near the plasma membrane in suspension cells was too weak to be imaged clearly.

Previous studies showed that DsRed-E5 changes its fluorescence color over time, shifting from green to red fluorescence after maturation. The ratio of green to red fluorescence can be used to estimate the age of the fusion protein (Terskikh et al., 2000;Mirabella et al., 2004). Therefore, we employed DsRed-E5 to label SYT2 and established a stably transformed Arabidopsis suspension cell line expressing SYT2-DsRed-E5 driven by a 35S promoter. The SYT2-DsRed-E5 fusion protein in suspension cells displayed a patchy distribution similar to that of SYT2-GFP in to-bacco and Arabidopsis pollen tubes. Moreover, SYT2-DsRed-E5 fluorescence signal was also clearly detected on the plasma membrane in the red fluorescence channel ( Figure 4A), while DsRed-E5 alone was diffusely distributed in the cytoplasm and inside the nuclei (Supplemental Figure 5C). A z-stack projection of the images in Figure 4A is shown in Figure 4B. By comparing the fluorescent lines on the cell periphery (indicated by arrows in Figure 4A and 4B) with the non-fluorescent trans-vacuolar cytoplasmic strands (indicated by arrows in Figure 4C), we inferred that the fine fluorescent lines were not on the tonoplast but on the plasma membrane. In addition, the plasmolysis assay indicated that SYT2 was not localized to the cell wall ( Figure 4D).

Detailed analysis of the punctate structures around the nucleus revealed that these spots emitted both green and red fluorescence. Moreover, green fluorescence on the punctate structures around the nucleus was considerably stronger than that on the plasma membrane, while the red fluorescence showed a less marked difference ( Figure 4A and 4C). This result indicated that the SYT2-DsRed-E5 proteins localized to the Golgi apparatus around the nucleus were newly synthesized and those localized to the plasma membrane represented the older SYT2-DsRed-E5 population.

To further characterize the spatiotemporal dynamics of SYT2-DsRed-E5, we performed quantitative analysis and calculated the ratio of green to red fluorescence intensity on vesicles around the nuclei (V 1 ), vesicles near the plasma membrane (V ), and the plasma membrane (M) from the original grayscale images ( Figure 5A). As shown in Figure 5B, the green fluorescence on both V 1 and V 2 vesicles was stronger than the red fluorescence, as the green/red signal ratio of V 1 was 7.6:1 and that of V 2 was 6.8:1 ( Figure 5B). Red fluorescence on the plasma membrane was stronger than the green fluorescence, as the green/red signal ratio of the plasma membrane was 1:5.2 ( Figure 5B). The intensities of green and red fluorescence signals of DsRed-E5 alone in the cells were similar, with a green/red signal ratio of 1.7 ( Figure 5B). A previous study reported that a red/green ratio R1 indicated that the DsRed-E5 protein was produced more than 10 h ago in vitro in Caenorhabditis elegans cells (Terskikh et al., 2000), and approximately more than 30 h ago in cowpea mesophyll protoplasts (Mirabella et al., 2004). This indicated that the majority of SYT2-DsRed-E5 proteins on the plasma membrane had been synthesized at least 10 h previously, which demonstrated that the SYT2 protein was transported from the Golgi apparatus to the plasma membrane over time.

div.head: SYT2 Is Transported to the Plasma Membrane via Conventional Secretion
div.p: We further examined the localization of SYT2-DsRed-E5 in the suspension cells after treatment with the secretion inhibitor BFA. Compared with untreated cells, cells treated with BFA for 20 and 40 min displayed enlarged SYT2 vesicle aggregates, and the fluorescence signal of SYT2-DsRed-E5 on the plasma membrane was reduced ( Figure 6 and Supplemental Figure 7). Quantitative analyses of the green/red fluorescence signal ratio of the vesicles and plasma membrane at different time points with BFA treatment are shown in Figure 6D. The results showed that the green/red fluorescence ratio of vesicles decreased over time following treatment with BFA. For the plasma membrane, the green/red fluorescence ratio was increased after BFA treatment ( Figure 6D). The intensities of DsRed-E5 green and red fluorescence signals in the suspension cells were approximately the same ( Figure 6D).

These results suggested that the newly synthesized SYT2-DsRed-E5 protein was mainly incorporated into the BFA compartments and was not transported to the plasma membrane, whereas old SYT2-DsRed-E5 protein seemed to be retained on the plasma membrane. The results showed clearly that SYT2 was transferred to the plasma membrane via the conventional secretory pathway in Arabidopsis suspension cells.

div.head: C2 Domains Are Crucial for Localization of SYT2 to the Plasma Membrane
div.p: Arabidopsis SYT2 contains two C2 domains, C2A and C2B. C2A was 62.4% similar to SYT1 and C2B was 73.5% similar to SYT1 (Supplemental Table 3). To characterize the role of C2 domains in the localization of SYT2, we created a potential dominantnegative SYT2 mutant lacking the C2A and C2B domains (SYT2 DC2AB ). Similar to SYT2-GFP, SYT2 DC2AB -GFP accumulated in distinct patches in the cytoplasm ( Figure 7A) and was highly co-localized with the C5-ceramide-stained Golgi apparatus ( Figure 7B). SYT2 DC2AB -DsRed-E5 also showed distinct patchy distribution in the cytoplasm ( Figure 7C), and there was no obvious difference between the distributions of SYT2 DC2AB -GFP and SYT2 DC2AB -DsRed-E5. However, unlike the full length of SYT2-DsRed-E5 (Figure 4), only a trace amount of SYT2 DC2AB -DsRed-E5 red fluorescence was detected on the plasma membrane ( Figure 7C). These results suggested that the C2 domains of SYT2 played a role in directing SYT2 to the plasma membrane.

div.head: The C2 Domains of SYT2 Show Calcium-Dependent Phospholipid Binding
div.p: We further investigated whether the C2 domains of SYT2 could bind to the negatively charged liposomes (25% phosphatidylserine [PS]/75% phosphatidylcholine [PC]), and found that the SYT2-C2A peptide was able to bind a phospholipid in a calcium-dependent manner ( Figure 8A). The maximum concentration of free Ca 2+ binding to SYT2-C2A was 7 mM, and a higher calcium ion concentration did not increase binding of SYT2-C2A to the liposomes. Moreover, binding of SYT2-C2B to the liposomes was calcium-independent ( Figure 8B). SYT2-C2B

was associated with liposomes in the absence of free Ca 2+ , and this binding was not enhanced by increased calcium concentration. The binding property of SYT2-C2AB differed from those of the two individual domains; indeed, SYT2-C2AB behaved as an approximate mixture of C2A and C2B. Half-maximal binding of C2AB to phospholipids was approximately 2-3 mM of free Ca 2+ ( Figure 8C), while that of C2A was about 4-5 mM ( Figure 8A). As controls, all the C2 domains of SYT2 were subjected to different concentrations of Na + and Mg 2+ . The effects of Na + (Supplemental Figure 8) and Mg 2+ (Supplemental Figure 9) on the binding of SYT2 C2 domains with liposomes were found to be insignificant. These data indicated that the C2 domains of SYT2 were bound to phospholipids in membranes and that this binding was regulated by calcium ions.

div.head: DISCUSSION
div.p: SYT2 belongs to a small gene family. In the Arabidopsis database (i.e., TAIR), there are five SYT genes containing one transmembrane domain and two C2 domains (Craxton, 2004). These genes may share a common ancestral gene, as the exonintron structures among the SYT genes are highly conserved (Yamazaki et al., 2010). Unlike the ubiquitous expression of SYT1 in Arabidopsis, we clearly demonstrated by promoter analysis that SYT2 was expressed mainly in the female and male gametophytes of Arabidopsis, especially in the developing embryo sacs, pollen grains, and the growing pollen tubes (Figure. 1A, 1F, and 1G). Semi-quantitative RT-PCR analysis also showed that SYT2 was highly expressed in stamens, particularly in pollen grains. The results from both promoter and RT-PCR analyses are in agreement with the microarray data for the At1G20080 gene available from the Genevestigator database (https://www.genevestigator.ethz.ch) (Zimmermann et al., 2004). All these data suggest that SYT2 plays a specific role in the development and growth of female and male gametophytes. Subcellular localization of synaptotagmins is essential to determine protein functions (Schapire et al., 2008). Previous reports showed that mammalian Syt1 and Syt7 are localized to synaptic vesicles and lysosomes, respectively, and are proposed to be Ca 2+ sensors regulating the neurotransmitter release and/or resealing of the plasma membrane (Brose et al., 1992;Reddy et al., 2001).
In this study, we found that SYT2-GFP was localized to the Golgi apparatus with a patchy distribution in Arabidopsis suspension

div.head: SYT2 in Pollen Tube Growth
div.p: Molecular Plant cells, as well as in pollen tubes, which was in accordance with Zhang et al. (2011). More information on the localization of SYT2 was obtained when SYT2 was fused with the fluorescent protein timer DsRed-E5 and expressed in suspension cells. SYT2-DsRed-E5 was localized to the plasma membrane as well as in distinct patches around the nuclei. This fluorescent timer showed that the newly synthesized SYT2 was first localized on the Golgi apparatus, and then transferred to the plasma membrane. Furthermore, the C2 domains were necessary to transport SYT2 from the Golgi apparatus to the plasma membrane. The secretion inhibitor BFA also prevented the transport of SYT2 to the plasma membrane. These results are similar to the description of the molecular function of animal synaptotagmins, which act as Ca 2+ sensors and trigger fusion of secretory vesicles with the plasma membrane.

Previous studies showed that Arabidopsis SYT1-GFP was localized mainly on the plasma membrane (Schapire et al., 2008;Yamazaki et al., 2008;Lewis and Lazarowitz, 2010), while Arabidopsis SYT2-GFP was rarely observed on the plasma membrane in our study and in a previous report (Zhang et al., 2011). A recent study also indicated that Arabidopsis SYT1-GFP is anchored at the ER, but not the plasma membrane, and was localized on the stationary ER-plasma membrane contact sites (Perez Sancho et al., 2015), while in our results SYT2-GFP and SYT2-DsRed-E5 were localized on the motile Golgi apparatus. These results provide evidence that the two SYTs are playing different roles in Arabidopsis. SYT1 is required to maintain the integrity of plasma membranes during freezing conditions (Yamazaki et al., 2008), osmotic stress (Schapire et al., 2008), and mechanical stress (Perez Sancho et al., 2015). On the other hand, SYT2 is required for pollen tube tip growth and for pollen viability. This implies that SYT2 may facilitate the constitutive secretion of substances to the plasma membrane and/or to the extracellular space that is important for pollen development and for pollen tube elongation.

It is interesting that SYT2-GFP signals were not detected on the plasma membrane in pollen tubes (Figure 3), suspension cells (Supplemental Figure 5), and root cells (Zhang et al., 2011), but SYT2-DsRed-E5 and anti-SYT2 antibody labeled both the Golgi apparatus and the plasma membrane (Figures 4-7 and Supplemental Figure 6). GFP (27 kDa) from the jellyfish Aequorea victoria has similar molecular weight and topology to DsRed monomer (28 kDa) from a coral of the Discosoma genus (Terskikh et al., 2002;Chudakov et al., 2010). However, DsRed shows a slow rate of fluorescence development and forms an obligate tetramer in vitro and in living cells (Baird et al., 2000;Yarbrough et al., 2001). We are proposing two possible scenarios explaining why SYT2-GFP cannot be transferred to the plasma membrane. First, the chemical property of GFP interrupts the interactions between the C2 domains of SYT2 and the plasma membrane or other protein components that are essential for the membrane fusion process. On the other hand, the effect of DsRed-E5 is less noticeable. Second, the clustering or oligomerization of SYT2 proteins is necessary Initially, the green fluorescence on V 0 was stronger than the red fluorescence (GF/RF > 1), while the red fluorescence on M 0 was stronger than the green fluorescence (GF/RF < 1). There was no obvious difference in the GF/RF ratio between V 0 and V 20 ; however, the GF/RF ratio of V 40 was significantly different from that of V (t-test, *p < 0.05). Compared with M , the RF/GF ratios of M 20 and M 40 were significantly increased (t-test, *p < 0.05 and **p < 0.01, respectively). To measure the fluorescence signals, 10 cells of each group were analyzed, and five vesicles were chosen randomly from each cell for statistical analysis. Error bars represented ±SE (n = 70). DIC, Differential Interference Contrast.

for the attachment or fusion of SYT2-localized vesicles to the plasma membrane. Fusion of GFP to the C terminus of SYT2 prevents this oligomerization while DsRed-E5 compensates this disruption by forming a tetramer, bringing SYT2 close enough to function properly in exocytosis. Since exocytosis can be divided into three steps, docking, priming, and release, further studies on how SYT2 interacts with other components may provide better understanding of the roles of SYT2 in exocytosis. Furthermore, we cannot exclude the possibility that DsRed-E5 also affects endocytosis for recycling the SYT2 back from the plasma membrane. More protein interactome analysis would be helpful to reveal the function of SYT2 in exocytosis/endocytosis. The functions of Arabidopsis synaptotagmins are often inferred from animal synaptotagmins, based on the similarity of the sequences and domain architectures. However, there is no direct evidence that plant synaptotagmins mediate membrane fusion in cells. This may be due to the difficulty in establishing a plant membrane fusion test system in vivo (Zarsky et al., 2009). Therefore, alternative methods must be used to obtain circumstantial evidence. The in vitro phospholipid-binding assay is a well-established system of determining whether a protein binds to phospholipid bilayers in a calcium-dependent or -independent manner. The Ca 2+ -binding affinity of animal Syt1, determined in vitro, is similar to the physiologically relevant concentrations in cells (Geppert et al., 1994). (A) SYT2-GFP localized on the Golgi apparatus, but not all C5 ceramidestained signals overlapped with SYT2-GFP. (B) The C-terminal tagged SYT2 DC2AB -GFP lacking C2AB domains showed a punctate distribution, and was localized to the C5 ceramidestained Golgi apparatus. (C) SYT2 DC2AB -DsRED-E5 localized to the Golgi apparatus, but not the plasma membrane. Bars represent 10 mm. DIC, Differential Interference Contrast. The C2A domain (A), C2B domain (B), and C2AB domain (C) of SYT2 were incubated with liposomes in the presence of the indicated concentrations of free Ca 2+ (clamped with Ca 2+ /EGTA buffers) to estimate partial binding of free Ca 2+ . The amino acid residues at positions 244-400 represent the C2A domain of SYT2, 401-537 represent the C2B domain of SYT2, and 247-537 represent the C2AB domain of SYT2. Purified GST fusion proteins containing the corresponding residues of SYT2 C2 domains were incubated in various concentrations of free Ca 2+ with liposomes composed of 25% PS/75% PC. Liposomes were precipitated by centrifugation, and bound proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE. The EC 50 for C2AB was 2-3 mM. Error bars represent ±SE (n = 3).
Molecular Plant --, 1-14, --2015 ª The Author 2015. 9 SYT2 in Pollen Tube Growth

div.head: Molecular Plant
div.p: In plant pollen tubes, intracellular Ca 2+ shows a tip-focused distribution (Gu et al., 2003). For example, cytosolic Ca 2+ concentrations in lily pollen tubes decline drastically from 3-5 mM at the extreme apex to basal levels (100-200 nM) within 20 mm (Pierson et al., 1994;Hepler et al., 2001). This tipfocused Ca 2+ gradient is required for pollen tube elongation, as it may facilitate fusion of secretory vesicles with the plasma membrane (Hepler et al., 2001;Helling et al., 2006).

In this report, the C2A domain of SYT2 acted as a Ca 2+ -dependent phospholipid-binding domain, while the C2B domain had Ca 2+ -independent phospholipid binding activity. The phospholipid binding property of the C2AB domain was also calcium dependent, with half-maximal binding occurring at 2-3 mM free Ca 2+ (Figure 8). This calcium-dependent binding property of SYT2 is correlated with the maximal calcium concentration at the pollen tube tips and supports the physiological function of SYT2 on transporting the secretory vesicles to the plasma membrane in the rapid-growing pollen tubes.

The N-terminal transmembrane domain of synaptotagmin is inserted into the membrane of secretory vesicles, and the C2 domains can bind to the target membrane under regulation of Ca 2+ (Jefferson et al., 1987). Our results showed that the C2 domains of SYT2 were important for the localization of SYT2 to the plasma membrane ( Figure 7C). However, the N-terminal transmembrane domain (amino acids 2-26) of SYT2 alone was sufficient for proper localization of SYT2 on the Golgi apparatus. This indicated that the transmembrane domains determined the localization of SYT2 on the Golgi apparatus, while the C2 domains facilitated its transfer to the plasma membrane.

The vitality of pollen grains has a marked effect on germination and growth of pollen tubes (Fan et al., 2001). The vigor of plants and flowers affects the vitality of their pollen grains. To minimize the differences in pollen vitality due to the differences in vigor of wild-type and mutant plants, flowers were selected according to strict criteria. In this study, we identified three T-DNA insertion mutants (syt2-1, syt2-2, and syt2-3) and obtained an RNAi mutant of SYT2. SYT2 mutations resulted in the reduction of pollen germination and shorter pollen tubes compared with the wild-type ( Figure 2D and 2E). The loss-of-function mutants of SYT2 had a slower rate of pollen tube growth (Supplemental Figure 4 and Supplemental Table 2). This phenotype was not obvious, and this experiment could be repeated only with very strict selection of flowers and plants.

This result implied that SYT2 mutations had a slight effect on the growth of pollen tubes, while other factors, such as the health of the plants, may have influenced pollen viability. The weak phenotype of SYT2 mutants may have been due to gene redundancy, since four other synaptotagmin genes (e.g., SYT1) could also be expressed in Arabidopsis pollen; these may compensate for the functional deficiencies of SYT2.

Arabidopsis SYT2 has been reported to play a role in unconventional secretion (Zhang et al., 2011). The proteins involved in unconventional secretion lack the typical N-terminal signal peptides and the export processes are not inhibited by BFA (Duran et al., 2010). For pollen tubes, our data showed that BFA inhibited transport of SYT2 to the plasma membrane and disrupted the normal localization of SYT2 on the Golgi apparatus in suspension cells ( Figure 6). In the tip-growing pollen tubes, SYT2 was involved in conventional secretion. This may be due to differences in the cell culture systems. We used pollen tubes and suspension cell cultures for subcellular localization, while a previous report used root cells and protoplasts (Zhang et al., 2011). Our study provides a new perspective for research on the role of SYT2 in Arabidopsis pollen tube growth and the function of the conventional secretory pathway.

div.head: Plant Growth Conditions
div.p: Arabidopsis (Col-0) seeds were planted in pots in a 3:1 nutritional soil/ vermiculite mix. After 2 days at 4 C, the seeds were grown with supplemental lighting (16-h photoperiod at 120-150 mmol/m 2 /s at 22 C Fan et al., 2001). Seeds of T-DNA insertion lines and RNAi transgenic lines were disinfected with 1% sodium hypochlorite and washed with sterile water, and then sown in Murashige and Skoog medium with 0.8% agar (Lalanne et al., 2004). The 2-week-old seedlings were then transferred to pots and grown for 4 weeks under the light conditions described above.

div.head: T-DNA Insertion Line
div.p: The Arabidopsis T-DNA insertion lines (SALK_133731, SALK_016690, and SALK_072947, identified as syt2-1, syt2-2, and syt2-3, respectively) were obtained from the SALK T-DNA collection. Homozygosity of mutant lines was confirmed by PCR analysis of genomic DNA, using the specific primers listed in Supplemental Table 1. The expression of the SYT2 gene in the homozygous mutant lines was determined by RT-PCR. PCR products were verified by sequencing.

div.head: RNAi Transgenic Lines
div.p: The sense and antisense DNA fragments of the SYT2 exon, amplified using specific primers (Supplemental Table 1), were subcloned into pFGC1008. The construct was transformed into the Arabidopsis genome using the Agrobacterium tumefaciens-mediated method. Hygromycin-resistant transgenic Arabidopsis plants were screened and confirmed by genomic PCR analysis by amplifying the GUS segment of pFGC1008. The expression of SYT2 in transgenic plants was confirmed by RT-PCR using the primer sets for real-time PCR (Supplemental Table 1).

div.head: RNA Isolation and RT-PCR
div.p: Total RNA was isolated from various plant tissues using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen), according to the manufacturer's instructions. A quantity of 5-mg total RNA was used for reverse transcription with the RevertAid First Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit (Fermentas), according to the manufacturer's instructions. Real-time PCR analysis was conducted using the SYBR Green PCR Master Mix (ABI), referring to the manufacturer's instructions. The data were processed using the 7000 SDS software. The Actin2 gene was used as an internal control (Thorlby et al., 2004;Nicot et al., 2005). The specific primers for each gene are listed in Supplemental Table 1. This experiment was conducted three times independently, and the means and standard deviations were calculated. For semi-quantitative RT-PCR, PCR analysis was performed on 15 ml using the GoTaq Hot Start Polymerase (Promega) on an Eppendorf Mastercycler Pro instrument (Eppendorf). The following amplification program was used: one cycle at C for 3 min, 35 cycles for SYT2 gene and 30 cycles for reference genes at 95 C for 15 s, 56 C for 30 s, 73 C for 30 s, and then one cycle at 73 C for 5 min. The primers are listed in Supplemental Table 1. Band intensities were analyzed using the ImageJ software. This experiment was repeated twice independently.

div.head: SYT2 Promoter Activity Analysis
div.p: A fragment of 2014 bp, upstream from the start codon in the gene At1G20080, was amplified using the primers listed in Supplemental Table 1 and cloned into the expression vector pCAMBIA1305.1, and then transformed into Arabidopsis by Agrobacterium tumefaciens. Homozygous lines were obtained and the histochemical GUS assays were performed as described (Jefferson et al., 1987). Protein was extracted with 50 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.3) supplemented with 10 mM EDTA, 0.1% (v/v) Triton X-100, 0.1% (w/v) SDS, and 10 mM dithiothreitol. The fluorometric analysis reaction was performed in black 96-well microtiter plates (NUNC) in darkness at 37 C. The 50 ml of extraction buffer contained 1 mM 4-methylumbelliferyl-b-D-glucuronide as substrate and 1 mg of total protein. After 1 h, the reaction was stopped by addition of 150 ml of carbonate buffer (200 mM) and fluorescence intensity was measured using a multidetection Tecan Infinite M20 microplate reader (Tecan Trading AG) with 362 (±9) nm excitation and 450 (±20) nm emission. Protein concentration was measured using the Lowry-based Bio-Rad DC protein assay (Bio-Rad).

div.head: In vitro Pollen Germination and Tube Length Measurements
div.p: Pollen grains from freshly anther-dehisced flowers of wild-type and mutant Arabidopsis plants were germinated in 35-mm petri dishes at room temperature for 5 h on basic medium (20% sucrose, 5 mM boric acid, 8 mM MgSO 4 , 5 mM CaCl 2 , 1 mM KCl, 10 mM inositol, and 5 mM MES-KOH [pH 7.0]; Fan et al., 2001), and observed using a Zeiss Observer Z1 microscope. At least 100 pollen tubes were chosen randomly for length measurements using Axio software (version 4.0). Pollen germination in this study refers to the length of pollen tube exceeding half the pollen diameter. Average lengths and standard errors over several hundred pollen tubes were computed. All experiments were repeated at least three times. All the fluorescent dyes and inhibitors were diluted in the basic medium with the final working concentrations indicated in the figure legends.

div.head: Generation and Purification of GST Fusion Proteins
div.p: DNA sequences encoding the C2A domain of SYT2 located from amino acids 244 to 400, the C2B domain (401-537), and C2AB tandem (247-537), were ligated into a pGEX-2z vector. Purification of GST fusion protein was carried out as described previously (Guan and Dixon, 1991;Schapire et al., 2008).

div.head: Phospholipid Binding Assays
div.p: Binding of C2 domains (C2A, C2B, and C2AB) of SYT2 to phospholipids was measured according to previous descriptions (Fernandez et al., 2001;Fernandez-Chacon et al., 2002;Shin et al., 2003;Schapire et al., 2008). Phospholipids (PS/PC = 25:75, w/w; Avanti Polar Lipids) were used in this experiment. Calcium concentrations were calculated using the Winmaxc32 (version 2.51) software downloaded from http://www. stanford.edu/cpatton/downloads.htm. The proteins were detected by SDS-PAGE. The Coomassie Brilliant Blue-stained gels were scanned using Bio-Rad ChemiDoc XRS and then analyzed using the Quantity One software.

div.head: Transformation of Tobacco and Arabidopsis Pollen Grains Using Particle Bombardment
div.p: Tobacco was planted in a controlled growth chamber at 25 C with 16 h daylight. The pollen grains were collected from anthers that had not dehisced on SR1 flowers. All plasmid DNA was prepared using the Ultra-Clean Endotoxin-Free Maxi Plasmid Prep Kit (Beijing ZEPING Bioscience). Golgi marker GmMan1-mCherry (G-rk, CD3-967) was purchased from the Arabidopsis stock center (http://www.arabidopsis.org). A quantity of 10 mg of mature pollen grains was used in each bombardment. Pollen germination medium (0.01% H BO 3 , 1 mM MgSO 4 , 5 mM CaCl 2 , 5 mM Ca(NO 3 ) 2 , 18% sucrose, and 20 mM MES [pH 6.5-7.0]) was prepared to incubate pollen grains (Fan et al., 2001). Pollen suspension was spotted and solidified on a nylon membrane in 90-mm petri dishes. Gene bombardment was performed using the helium-driven PDS-1000/He system (Bio-Rad). Plasmid DNA, 0.1 M spermidine, and 2.5 M CaCl were attached to gold particles (1 mm), according to the Bio-Rad manual (Sanford et al., 1993;Chen et al., 2002). A total of 3 mg of DNA was used to coat 1 mg of gold particles. Each prepared sample was bombarded twice toward an individual pollen sample to improve the frequency of transformation. Bombardments were performed under the following conditions: 71-cm (28-inch) Hg chamber vacuum, 1100-psi rupture disc, 6.4 mm (0.25-inch) gap distance, and 2.5-cm (1 inch) particle travel distance. Boomed pollen grains were washed from the nylon membrane using germination medium and germinated in 35-mm petri dishes with shaking at 60 rpm in the dark. Pollen tubes were observed using an Olympus FV300-IX700 laser scanning confocal microscope. Images were analyzed using an FV1000 viewer (version 1.6).

div.head: Transformation of Arabidopsis Callus Cells
div.p: Stable transformation of Arabidopsis callus (induced from seeds of Col-0 ecotype) was performed using Agrobacterium tumefaciens (strain GV3101) according to methods described previously (Dhonukshe and Gadella, 2003). The plant expression vector pCAMBIA1300.1, containing 35S-SYT2-GFP-tNOS, 35S-SYT2 DC2AB -GFP-tNOS, 35S-GFP-tNOS, 35S-SYT2-DsRed-E5-tNOS, 35S-SYT2 DC2AB -DsRed-E5-tNOS, and 35S-DsRed-E5-tNOS constructs, was used for transformation.

div.head: Microscopy
div.p: Confocal microscopy was performed using an Olympus FV-300-IX70 confocal laser scanning microscope. ER-Tracker Blue-White DPX was excited with the diode laser (405 nm) and the emission was detected between 425 and 475 nm. GFP was excited with the blue argon ion laser (488 nm), and emitted light was collected through a 510-nm long-pass filter. The red fluorescent dyes FM4-64 and BODIPY TR C5 ceramide (B-34400; Invitrogen) were excited with a green HeNe laser (543 nm), and emitted light was collected through a 620-nm bandpass filter. The excitation/emission wavelengths of DsRed-E5 were 483/500 nm for green fluorescence and 558/583 nm for red fluorescence. Differential interference contrast microscopy images were collected synchronously. Images were analyzed using an Olympus FV1000 viewer (version 1.6). A 360 oilimmersion objective was used for scanning. Serial confocal optical sections were taken at a step size of 0.5-0.7 mm.

div.head: SUPPLEMENTAL INFORMATION
div.p: Supplemental Information is available at Molecular Plant Online.

div.head: FUNDING
div.p: The work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant nos. 31070220 and 30771087), the National Basic Research Program of China (grant no. 2013CB126902). Part of the work of W.S. and F.B. was supported by DAAD (German Academic Exchange Service). J.J., K.M., and J.T. were supported by the Research and Development Operational Program ''Comenius University Science Park'' (ERDF, ITMS 26240220086).

Vesicles around the nucleus (blue) show green (GF) and red (RF) fluorescence. The plasma membrane shows only RF. Arrows indicate the fluorescent lines on the cell periphery. (B) Z-stack projection of (A). This image is derived from stacks of 10 sections. The arrows in (A and B) indicate SYT2 vesicles close to the plasma membrane. Arrows indicate the fluorescent lines on the cell periphery. (C) No fluorescence was found on trans-vacuolar cytoplasmic strands or the tonoplast. Arrows indicate the non-fluorescent trans-vacuolar cytoplasmic strands. (D) Plasmolysis of a p35S:SYT2-DsRED-E5 Arabidopsis thaliana L. suspension cell shows no fluorescence on the cell wall. Arrows parallel with an asterisk indicate the cell wall, while arrows parallel with two asterisks indicate the plasma membrane. Bars represent 10 mm. DIC, Differential Interference Contrast.

Aa, the control DsRED-E5 fluorescence shows green and red fluorescence signals of similar intensities. figure.head: Figure 6 .
figure.figDesc: BFA Treatment Prevents SYT2-DeRED-E5 Transfer to the Plasma Membrane in p35S:SYT2-DsRED-E5-Overexpressing Arabidopsis thaliana L. Suspension Cells. (A) p35S:SYT2-DsRED-E5-overexpressing Arabidopsis thaliana L. suspension cells without BFA treatment. Vesicles (V 0 ) showed predominantly green fluorescence, while the plasma membrane (M 0 ) showed predominantly red fluorescence. Bar represents 5 mm. (B) Arabidopsis thaliana L. suspension cells stably expressing SYT2-DsRED-E5 were treated with 50 mM BFA for 20 min. Bar represents 5 mm. (C) Arabidopsis thaliana L. suspension cells stably expressing SYT2-DsRED-E5 were treated with 50 mM BFA for 40 min. SYT2-positive vesicles (V 40 ) aggregate to larger compartments. Vesicles (V 40 ) showed stronger green fluorescence signals, while the plasma membrane (M 40 ) showed weaker red fluorescence signals. Bar represents 5 mm. (D) Analyses of the green and red fluorescence ratio of SYT2-DsRED-E5 protein after BFA treatment. V 0 indicates vesicles without BFA treatment and M 0 indicates plasma membrane without BFA treatment. V 20 and M 20 indicate 20 min of BFA treatment; V 40 and M 40 indicate 40 min of BFA treatment.
